awd_titl_txt: Research Initiation: Leveraging Systems Thinking to Enhance the Holistic Formation of Engineers
awd_abstract_narration:
As the world becomes increasingly complex, systems thinking continues to gain recognition as an important and necessary skill for future engineers.  Systems thinking does not replace traditional technical skills required of engineers, but instead provides a complementary skill set to help better navigate complex systems and their corresponding problems.  Systems thinking is defined as a way of framing how we see, interpret, make sense, and respond to the complex world we encounter on a daily basis. The increasing complexity of U.S. industries demands that universities train engineers with systems thinking skills to solve the range of interconnected problems companies may face. This project aims to understand the ability of engineering students to think at a system level in order to better fit their future engineering careers.  The project provides essential insights into the preparation of 21st century engineering students with respect to systems thinking capability.  By comparing student capabilities to the needs of employers, the current state of engineering education can be evaluated and modified.  Better understanding students' systems thinking capability, as well as factors that may influence their capability, provides engineering educators with new knowledge to better inform preparation of future engineering students. This project helps to answer the need to have a large number of qualified engineers available for U.S. industry that can engage in higher levels of thinking required in complex systems problem domains. 
 
The project addresses a recognized challenge of current engineering formation: how to prepare future holistic engineers to better handle complex multidisciplinary problems. While systems thinking has been recognized as one of the essential skills for future engineers, measurement of systems thinking capability in this project will provide new insights.  The project has three primary tasks: 1) evaluate current engineering students' systems thinking capability, using a previously validated survey instrument, and connect systems thinking capability to the established theoretical frameworks (inductive and deductive reasoning) 2) identify and explore various cognitive, demographic, academic, and intuitional factors that influence systems thinking capability; and 3) evaluate employers' needs to investigate gaps between students' systems thinking capacity and employers' needs. The grounding of systems thinking capability in the theory of inductive and deductive reasoning offers potentially transformative research for understanding the development of systems thinking.  The comparison between student capability and employer needs will provide useful insights for engineering educators.  In addition to assessing student capability, and comparing it to employer needs, this project identifies the underlying factors that influence systems thinking capability, providing theoretical guidance to the existing systems engineering body of knowledge. The implementation of the project tasks will enhance and foster the current state of engineering education knowledge and project systems thinking skills beyond the classroom. Therefore, engineering students will be better prepared for their future engineering careers and fill the U.S. industry's needs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

por.por_cntn:
We have four major broader impacts components and three main  to our project: (1) graduate student training, (2) faculty training, (3) dissemination to professional societies, and (4) K-12 outreach for systems thinking. 

Graduate Student Training: We have continued to fund two graduate research assistant (Morteza Nagahi and Siham Tazzit) on this project in the second and last year of the project. They were included in mentoring sessions as research theories and methods were introduced to the junior faculties. they have also contributed significantly to the advanced analysis used in this project.

Faculty Training: With regard to faculty training, an outreach activity was conducted with the Military Academy to train faculty members on the use and implications of systems thinking tools and techniques. The materials developed include the training course along with the presented modules.

Dissemination:  A poster for the NSF grantee poster presentation meeting at the 2020 American Society of Engineering Education annual meeting was developed. Unfortunately, the above-mentioned meeting was canceled. However, a poster for this meeting was developed. We will submit an NSF grantee poster for the upcoming American Society for Engineering Education Annual Conference. We are currently have two other journal papers that are under preparation, the objective of the first paper is to identify the demographic factors that would predict students systems thinking capability, and the second paper is to perform a gap analysis to compare students? skillset to employers?? expectations and identify area for improvement in terms of curriculum.

K-12 Outreach: A Systems Thinking outreach activity was developed and pilot tested as a part of this project.  This outreach activity is intended to demonstrate the importance of systems thinking to students.  In this activity, we showed how engineers might leverage systems thinking to improve the performance of a supply chain. The materials developed include an instructor?s manual, team role worksheet, scorekeeper worksheet, and PowerPoint presentation.  These materials are provided in the attachment named ?Systems Thinking for Crazy Times.pdf.?

 

The activity was designed for students in grades 7-12, though it may also be a useful activity in an introductory college setting.  Students are divided into teams and each team member plays a role within the supply chain (manufacturer, retailer, customer).  Teams try to make the most profit from their enterprise.   In each round, various aspects of systems thinking are introduced to allow students to learn about the impact systems thinking can have on profit and performance. With regards to pilot testing of the activity, we completed a pilot test virtually (via WebEx) with a group of college students.  The activity was well received.  Due to the pandemic, we were not been able to do the outreach activity with high school students. 

 

Outreach for systems thinking: Another outreach activity was developed and pilot tested was with the United States Air Force Academy. This outreach activity is intended to demonstrate the implications and applications  of systems thinking to students. We have also examined the level of systems thinking skills for the United States Air Force Academy students.

 

Main outcomes:

  1. A preview of the STQ Environment instrument survey and demographic factors survey questions can be reached at the following website: https://msuas.co1.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_2lc7PxRDNW0VXSt
  2. A preview of individual systems thinking survey for the Airforce Academy students and demographic questions can be reached at the following website: https://msuas.co1.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_3kFLi2TPfeQkKBn
  3. A preview of individual systems thinking survey for the Military cadets and demographic questions can be reached at the following website: https://msuas.co1.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_3kFLi2TPfeQkKBn

 

 


Last Modified: 01/11/2022
Modified by: Raed M Jaradat

Images (1 of )
  • The mean of total aggregate ST score across all engineering students was 43.87%, with a standard deviation of 11.10. Total aggregate ST scores of engineering students in the sample of the population ranged from 10.30 (more toward less systemic extreme) to 79.50 (more toward the systemic extreme).
